The "soldiers" (*al-junud*) referenced here are interpreted by classical Shia commentators as the tyrannical armies of past nations—such as Pharaoh’s forces or the persecutors of early believers—who sought to extinguish the light of faith. Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, specifies that this verse introduces the subsequent account of the People of the Ditch (Ashab al-Ukhdud, verses 4–8), who burned believers alive for their unwavering faith, symbolising the eternal struggle between truth and falsehood.

Shia exegesis emphasises the theological principle that divine justice inevitably prevails over worldly oppression, a theme deeply rooted in the sufferings of the Ahl al-Bayt. The "soldiers" are not merely historical figures but represent all temporal powers that oppose divine guidance, including those who oppressed the Household of the Prophet (peace be upon them). Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) is reported to have linked such Quranic accounts to the trials faced by the Imams, asserting that their steadfastness epitomises the Quranic ideal of patient endurance (*sabr*) under persecution.

This verse also underscores the Shia doctrinal focus on *imamah* (divinely appointed leadership), as the triumph of truth is inseparable from allegiance to the guided successors of the Prophet. The narrative reinforces the belief that temporal power, when divorced from divine mandate, inevitably collapses—a concept mirrored in Shia jurisprudence, which prioritises moral and spiritual authority over coercive rule. Thus, the verse serves as both a historical reminder and an eschatological assurance: just as past oppressors faced divine retribution, so too will the forces opposing the Ahl al-Bayt be vanquished in the ultimate manifestation of justice through the Mahdi (aj)

The “soldiers” here symbolize both historical persecutors (like the tyrants who burned believers in the trench, as narrated in later verses) and modern structures of injustice—corrupt governance, economic exploitation, or ideological extremism. Scholar Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali notes that the verse’s interrogative tone (“Has it reached you?”) invites self-reflection: Are we attuned to the recurring patterns of oppression in our era?

Modern applications extend to systemic racism, climate injustice, and digital authoritarianism. The “soldiers” today might manifest as algorithms surveilling dissent, corporations exploiting labor, or policies marginalizing refugees. Philosophically, the verse challenges us to recognize complicity in silence; as philosopher Dr. Liyakat Takim argues, Qur’anic narratives of resistance urge proactive solidarity, not passive empathy. Scientifically, studies on collective trauma (e.g., Dr. Gabor Maté’s work on societal stress) parallel the Qur’an’s focus on the psychological toll of oppression—a theme echoed in the survivors of the trench.

Interfaith dialogues amplify this message: Jewish texts memorialize Pharaoh’s oppression, Buddhist teachings reject harm (*ahimsa*), and Christian liberation theology prioritizes the marginalized. Multiculturally, the verse underscores universal dignity—a principle enshrined in the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals but often ignored in practice. For Shia communities, this verse resonates with the legacy of Imam Hussain’s stand at Karbala, framing resistance to tyranny as both spiritual duty and social imperative. In an age of fragmented truths, Al-Burooj becomes a call to dismantle modern “soldiers” of injustice through ethical courage and intersectional activism.

In the luminous verse of Surah Al-Burooj (85:17), Allah invites reflection upon "the story of the soldiers" – a profound allusion to the eternal struggle between divine truth and oppressive forces. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) taught that these "soldiers" symbolize both physical armies opposing prophets and Imams, as well as the inner battalions of ego and misguidance that besiege the human soul. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) states: "Every verse of the Quran has an outer meaning and an inner meaning… The 'soldiers' are the enemies of the Ahlul Bayt in every age, but also the whispers of Satan that march against the heart seeking light."

This verse echoes the trials faced by the People of the Ditch (Ashab al-Ukhdud) mentioned later in the Surah – a metaphor for all who endure persecution for upholding Tawhid and Wilayah. Lady Fatimah (sa) emphasized that true spiritual soldiers are those who "fortify their hearts with remembrance of Allah and allegiance to His Proof [the Imam of their time]," as recorded in *Bihar al-Anwar*. The Imams taught that resisting oppression begins by conquering one’s own base desires through daily mujahadah (struggle), aligning one’s will with the divine guardianship embodied in the Imamah.

Practical wisdom from Imam Ali (as) illuminates the path: "Your worst enemy is the self between your sides; subdue it with the sword of hunger, the spear of humility, and the shield of night prayers" (*Ghurar al-Hikam*). Here, the "soldiers" become the disciplined practices of fasting, humility, and tahajjud that dismantle inner tyranny. To embody this verse is to join the ranks of those who defend truth through both outward justice and inward purification, recognizing that the Imam’s spiritual authority (Wilayah) is the fortress against all forms of despotism.

امام علی (ع) کی طرف سے عملی حکمت اس راستے کو روشن کرتی ہے: "آپ کا بدترین دشمن آپ کے فریقوں کے درمیان خود ہے۔ اسے بھوک کی تلوار ، عاجزی کا نیزہ ، اور رات کی دعاؤں کی ڈھال سے دوچار کریں" (*گھورار الحکام*)۔ یہاں ، "سپاہی" روزے ، عاجزی اور طاہجد کے نظم و ضبط کے طریق کار بن جاتے ہیں جو اندرونی ظلم کو ختم کرتے ہیں۔ اس آیت کو مجسمہ بنانا ان لوگوں کی صفوں میں شامل ہونا ہے جو ظاہری انصاف اور باطنی دونوں تزکیہ کے ذریعہ سچائی کا دفاع کرتے ہیں ، یہ تسلیم کرتے ہیں کہ امام کا روحانی اختیار (ولیہ) ہر طرح کے استبداد پسندی کے خلاف قلعہ ہے۔

In Surah Al-Burooj (85:18), Allah references two archetypal oppressors: "Fir’awna wa Thamud" (Pharaoh and Thamud), serving as eternal warnings against tyranny and rejection of divine truth. The verse comes amid a broader discussion about historical communities who persecuted believers, like the "Ashab al-Ukhdud" (People of the Ditch) mentioned earlier in the surah. By pairing Pharaoh—the quintessential arrogant ruler who enslaved the Israelites and opposed Prophet Musa (AS)—with Thamud, the tribe that rejected Prophet Salih (AS) and slaughtered the sacred she-camel, the Quran underscores a recurring pattern: civilizations crumble when they elevate power over piety and mock divine signs.

The Arabic term "Thamud" refers not just to a tribe but to a mindset of stubbornness; they demanded miracles from Prophet Salih (AS) yet defiantly destroyed the very sign they requested. Similarly, "Fir’awn" embodies unchecked authority that deifies itself, as Pharaoh famously declared, "I am your supreme lord" (Quran 79:24). Shia tafsir, as emphasized by scholars like Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, highlights how these stories validate the Quranic principle that oppression inevitably incurs divine accountability, even if delayed. The Ahlul Bayt (AS) taught that such verses remind believers to align with justice, not power—a lesson crystallized in Imam Hussain’s (AS) stand against Yazid’s tyranny.

Today, this verse calls Muslims to recognize modern "Pharaohs" and "Thamud" in systems that normalise injustice, whether through economic exploitation, religious persecution, or moral corruption. It urges self-reflection: do we, in subtle ways, prioritise worldly authority over ethical principles? The stories of Pharaoh and Thamud are not ancient relics but living mirrors, challenging us to side with the oppressed, uphold truth despite social pressure, and trust in Allah’s ultimate justice—a justice that transcends time and worldly power structures.
18.layer2:
In Surah al-Burooj (85:18), the reference to "Pharaoh and Thamud" serves as a paradigmatic warning against systemic oppression of divine truth, interpreted through classical Shia exegesis as both historical reality and enduring moral lesson. As articulated in Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, these nations epitomize the archetypal adversaries of God’s messengers—Pharaoh symbolizing political tyranny (ẓulm siyasi) and Thamud representing societal corruption (fasād ijtima'i). Their mention in this context underscores the Quran’s recurring theme: divine justice inevitably dismantles structures of disbelief, no matter how entrenched.

Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* expands this framework theologically, noting that the verse’s placement after the account of the People of the Ditch (Ashab al-Ukhdud) creates a typological chain linking all oppressors of God’s chosen guides. From a Shia perspective, this continuity extends to the persecution faced by the Ahl al-Bayt, particularly Imam Husayn at Karbala, framing their struggle as part of an eternal cosmic conflict between truth and falsehood. The verse thus transcends mere historical allusion, becoming a lens through which later events of sacred history are interpreted.

Scholars like Shaykh al-Tusi emphasize that Pharaoh’s rejection of Musa (as) and Thamud’s defiance of Salih (as) share a common root: the denial of *walayah* (divinely ordained authority). In Shia doctrine, this denial constitutes the gravest transgression, as it severs the connection between creation and the *nur* (light) of guidance manifested through prophets and Imams. The verse’s rhetorical question form—implied in the Arabic structure—invites reflection on the fate of such rejecters, reinforcing the principle of *ʿiqāb* (divine retribution) central to Shia theodicy.

Jurisprudentially, this verse underpins the Shia emphasis on resisting tyrannical power (taghut), as exemplified in the Imams’ teachings on enjoining good and forbidding evil. It also affirms the doctrinal position that divine justice operates beyond temporal constraints, assuring ultimate accountability for oppressors—a tenet that has sustained Shia communities through cycles of historical persecution.
18.layer3:
In Surah Al-Burooj (85:18), the Qur'an references Pharaoh and Thamud as archetypes of systemic oppression and civilizational collapse. Contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi and thinkers such as Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali emphasize that these narratives aren’t mere historical footnotes but urgent mirrors for modern societies. Pharaoh symbolizes tyrannical power structures that dehumanize dissenters, while Thamud – known for arrogantly rejecting Prophet Salih and destroying their sacred she-camel – represents societies that exploit natural resources and rupture ecological balance for short-term gain.  

Modern tafsir connects these stories to current crises: authoritarian regimes silencing human rights advocates (echoing Pharaoh’s oppression of Moses’ followers) and corporate greed driving climate disasters (paralleling Thamud’s environmental recklessness). Philosopher Dr. Shomali notes that the verse’s pairing of political and ecological hubris invites reflection on today’s "double tyranny" – where marginalized communities disproportionately suffer from both state violence and environmental degradation.  

Interfaith parallels emerge here: Jewish and Christian traditions share Pharaoh’s narrative, while Indigenous cosmologies globally warn against violating natural covenants, much like Thamud’s transgression. This verse challenges multicultural societies to build coalitions against structural injustice – whether supporting climate refugees or resisting censorship of truth-tellers like modern-day "Salihs" in journalism or activism.  

The Qur’anic warning transcends time: civilizations crumble not by divine whimsy but through ethical failures to honor human dignity and planetary stewardship. As contemporary scholar Dr. Liyakat Takim observes, "The ashes of Pharaoh and Thamud are scattered in every drone strike and melting glacier." Their stories demand that we interrogate power, privilege, and our relationship with Earth – making Al-Burooj 85:18 a rallying cry for transformative justice today.
18.layer4:
The verse referencing Pharaoh and Thamud in Surah al-Burooj (85:18) serves as a profound reminder of the eternal struggle between divine truth and oppressive forces. The Ahlul Bayt (as) taught that these historical nations symbolize not only physical tyranny but enduring spiritual patterns of rejecting *Wilayah* (divine guardianship) and persecuting the upholders of truth. Imam Ali (as) states in Nahj al-Balagha: *"Every era has its Pharaoh, and every Pharaoh has his Musa"*—revealing that the battle between truth and falsehood renews in every age through the Imamah and its opponents.  

The Sixth Imam, Ja'far al-Sadiq (as), explains in Tafsir al-Qummi that Pharaoh represents those who arrogantly deny Allah's signs out of love for worldly power, while Thamud symbolizes those who reject divine mercy after clear proofs—a warning against hardening one’s heart to the guidance of the Imams. Lady Fatimah (as) emphasized this in her Fadak sermon, linking oppression against the Ahlul Bayt (as) to the same arrogance that led past nations to destruction: *"You imitate the ummah who fought their Prophets and squandered their trusts."*  

Spiritually, this verse calls believers to recognize modern "Pharaohs" within their own souls—desires for dominance, heedlessness of divine justice, or neglect of the Imam’s spiritual authority. The practical remedy lies in nurturing *Tawalli* (love for the Imams) and *Tabarri* (disassociation from tyranny), as taught by Imam Muhammad al-Baqir (as): *"Hold fast to the rope of Allah [Wilayah], and let not the fire of greed consume your hearts as it consumed Pharaoh."* By aligning with the Imams’ teachings, one transforms into a fortress against inner and outer corruption, embodying the resilience of Prophet Musa (as) against every modern Pharaoh.

انٹر فیتھ کے متوازی یہاں سامنے آتے ہیں: یہودی اور عیسائی روایات فرعون کی داستان بیان کرتی ہیں ، جبکہ دیسی کاسمولوجی عالمی سطح پر قدرتی عہدوں کی خلاف ورزی کے خلاف انتباہ کرتے ہیں ، جیسے تھامود کی سرکشی کی طرح۔ اس آیت میں کثیر الثقافتی معاشروں کو ساختی ناانصافی کے خلاف اتحاد پیدا کرنے کے لئے چیلنج کیا گیا ہے-چاہے وہ آب و ہوا کے مہاجرین کی مدد کرے یا صحافت یا سرگرمی میں جدید دور کے "سالہ" جیسے سچ بولنے والوں کی سنسرشپ کی مزاحمت کرے۔  

قرآنی انتباہ وقت سے تجاوز کرتا ہے: تہذیبیں الہی سنبھل کے ذریعہ نہیں بلکہ اخلاقی ناکامیوں کے ذریعہ انسانی وقار اور سیاروں کی ذمہ داری کا احترام کرنے کے لئے گرتی ہیں۔ جیسا کہ ہم عصر اسکالر ڈاکٹر لییاکات تکیم نے مشاہدہ کیا ہے ، "فرعون اور تھامود کی راکھ ہر ڈرون ہڑتال اور پگھلنے والے گلیشیر میں بکھر جاتی ہے۔" ان کی کہانیوں کا مطالبہ ہے کہ ہم اقتدار ، استحقاق اور زمین کے ساتھ ہمارے تعلقات سے پوچھ گچھ کریں-البوروج 85:18 کو آج تبدیلی کے انصاف کے ل a ایک ریلنگ رونے کی آواز بناتے ہیں۔

19.layer1:
In Surah Al-Burooj verse 19, Allah states: *"Balil-ladhīna kafarū fī takdhīb"* ("But they who disbelieve are in [persistent] denial"). This verse highlights the entrenched mindset of those who reject divine truth, emphasizing their deliberate and continuous denial (*takdhīb*) rather than mere ignorance. The term *kafarū* (disbelieve) derives from *kufr*, meaning to "cover" or "conceal" the truth, suggesting an active choice to oppose faith despite awareness. *Takdhīb* here is a forceful, ongoing rejection, not a passive doubt—a pattern seen in those who stubbornly resist guidance even when faced with clear signs.

Historically, this verse connects to the persecution of early believers referenced earlier in the surah, particularly the story of the People of the Ditch (*Ashab al-Ukhdood*), where tyrants tortured monotheists for their faith. The disbelievers’ denial here isn’t intellectual skepticism but a moral failure—a refusal to submit to truth due to arrogance or vested interests. Classical Shia tafsir scholars like Allamah Tabatabai explain that such denial often stems from attachment to power, social norms, or materialism, blinding people to spiritual realities.

For modern Muslims, this verse serves as a caution against complacency in recognizing truth. It calls for self-reflection: Are we, in subtle ways, denying divine principles—like justice, compassion, or accountability—when they inconvenience us? In an age where moral relativism and oppression persist, the verse reminds believers to actively uphold truth, as taught by the Ahlul Bayt, who faced persecution yet remained steadfast. It urges Muslims to confront personal and societal falsehoods, whether in ignoring ethical responsibilities, normalizing injustice, or prioritizing worldly gains over spiritual growth. True faith, as Imam Ali taught, requires aligning actions with truth, even when it demands courage.
19.layer2:
In his monumental exegesis *Al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates that the verse "But they who disbelieve are in [persistent] denial" (85:19) transcends mere rejection of prophetic revelation, encapsulating a deeper ontological resistance to divine truth. Drawing from the linguistic root *k-dh-b* (to deny or falsify), Tabatabai emphasizes that *takdhib* here signifies a deliberate, entrenched opposition to the reality of God’s signs (*ayat*) and the cosmic order they manifest. This denial, he argues, is not passive ignorance but an active defiance rooted in spiritual arrogance (*istikbar*), a theme recurrent in Qur’anic depictions of Pharaoh and other archetypal oppressors.  

Shia commentators like Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* contextualize this verse within the surah’s broader narrative of persecuted believers (the People of the Ditch) and their oppressors. The "denial" is interpreted as a rejection of both prophetic mission and the divinely ordained authority (*wilayah*) of the Ahl al-Bayt, whom Shia theology regards as the延续 of divine guidance after the Prophet. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, as cited in classical sources, links such denial to the refusal to acknowledge the Imam’s station as the *hujjah* (proof) of God, rendering it a spiritual corruption (*fsq*) severing the soul from its covenantal bond (*mithaq*) with the Divine.  

Theologically, this verse underscores the Shia principle that unbelief (*kufr*) is not merely doctrinal error but a volitional rupture in recognizing the *nur* (light) of guidance vested in the Prophets and Imams. Such denial carries eschatological consequences, as the surah later juxtaposes the fate of deniers with the eternal reward of the steadfast. Within Shia jurisprudence, this informs the ethical imperative to uphold truth against oppression, reflecting the enduring struggle between *haqq* (truth) and *batil* (falsehood) central to Imami thought. Classical commentators unanimously stress that the verse’s warning extends beyond historical communities to all who, in any era, reject the interconnected realities of tawhid, nubuwwah, and imamah.
19.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Burooj (85:19) is often interpreted as a profound critique of systemic denialism—not merely theological rejection, but the active refusal to engage with truth in all its forms. Ayatollah Jafar Subhani, in his exegesis, emphasizes that "taktheeb" (denial) here transcends simple disbelief; it reflects a *willful* resistance to ethical and intellectual accountability, a theme echoed in modern discussions about climate denial, vaccine hesitancy, or historical revisionism. Scholar Dr. Liyakat Takim links this to the "cognitive dissonance" described in psychology, where entrenched ideologies override empirical evidence—a dynamic seen in political propaganda or corporate greenwashing.  

Philosophically, the verse speaks to humanity’s struggle with relativism. Grand Ayatollah Makarem Shirazi notes that denial often arises from fear of losing power or privilege, mirroring modern debates on racial justice and economic inequality. For instance, the refusal to acknowledge systemic racism or colonial harm aligns with the Quranic warning against those who "bury truth under falsehood" (2:42).  

Interfaith parallels emerge here: Buddhist teachings on "avidya" (ignorance) and Christian critiques of hypocrisy resonate with this verse’s call for intellectual humility. In multicultural societies, the verse invites dialogue on shared ethical responsibilities—such as combating misinformation or upholding human dignity.  

Today, as AI deepfakes and algorithmic echo chambers amplify denialism, this verse urges proactive truth-seeking anchored in the Ahlul Bayt’s legacy of critical inquiry. It challenges believers to confront modern "idols" of complacency and polarization, framing faith not as passive ritual but as a dynamic resistance to falsehood—a mission as urgent now as in seventh-century Arabia.
19.layer4:
The verse "But they who disbelieve are in [persistent] denial" (85:19) unveils a profound spiritual truth about the nature of *kufr* (disbelief) as a state of willful blindness to divine realities. The Ahlul Bayt (as) teach that this "denial" is not mere intellectual rejection but a refusal to submit to the luminous truth embodied in *Wilayah* (divine guardianship). Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) states: *"The deniers mentioned here are those who reject the guardians of Allah’s covenant – their denial is a veil over their hearts, not their eyes."*  

This verse points to the recurring pattern of humanity rejecting divine guides. Just as Pharaoh denied Musa (as) despite clear signs, many reject the light of Imamah due to arrogance and attachment to worldly illusions. Lady Fatimah (as) warned in her historic sermon: *"The most severe blindness is the blindness of the heart after clear witnessing."* The "persistent denial" refers to those who, despite witnessing truth through the Prophet’s progeny, choose to harden their souls against the fountain of *ma'rifah* (divine recognition).  

Practically, this verse calls believers to self-reflect: Do we deny truth in subtler forms – through neglecting obligations to the Imam of our time, or prioritizing desires over divine guidance? The Sixth Imam (as) taught: *"True faith is recognizing the Light and following it without hesitation; denial is seeing the Light yet walking toward shadows."*  

To escape this spiritual trap, one must anchor in the *thaqalayn* – the Quran and Ahlul Bayt. Daily recitation of Dua al-Ahad, seeking nearness to the Hidden Imam (aj), and embodying justice in actions become antidotes to the poison of denial. As Imam Ali (as) advised: *"Polish your hearts with remembrance of the True Guide, lest they rust with the corrosion of doubt.

مذہبی طور پر ، یہ آیت شیعہ کے اصول کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے کہ کفر (*کوفر*) محض نظریاتی غلطی نہیں ہے بلکہ انبیاء اور اماموں میں رہنمائی کے*نور*(روشنی) کو تسلیم کرنے میں ایک مستحکم ٹوٹنا ہے۔ اس طرح کی تردید کے نتیجے میں ساکٹولوجیکل نتائج برآمد ہوتے ہیں ، کیونکہ بعد میں سور surah نے ثابت قدمی کے دائمی اجر کے ساتھ انکار کی قسمت کا تعاقب کیا۔ شیعہ فقہ کے اندر ، اس سے ظلم کے خلاف سچائی کو برقرار رکھنے کے لئے اخلاقی لازمی مطلع کیا جاتا ہے ، جو * حق * (سچ) اور * بٹیل * (باطل) کے مابین مستقل جدوجہد کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔ کلاسیکی مبصرین متفقہ طور پر اس بات پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ آیت کی انتباہ تاریخی برادریوں سے آگے ان تمام لوگوں تک پھیلا ہوا ہے جو کسی بھی دور میں ، توہید ، نوبوہ اور امامہ کے باہم مربوط حقائق کو مسترد کرتے ہیں۔

20.layer1:
In Surah Al-Burooj verse 20, Allah declares, *"Wa Allahu min wara'ihim muheet"* – "While Allah encompasses them from behind." This verse comes in the context of a powerful narrative about the persecution of believers by tyrants, referencing the "People of the Ditch" (Ashab al-Ukhdood) who burned faithful men and women for their belief in Allah. The verse serves as both a warning and a reassurance: while oppressors may plot against the righteous, divine awareness surrounds them completely, leaving no escape from accountability.  

The term *muheet* (encompassing) signifies Allah’s all-encompassing knowledge and power, which transcends time, space, and human perception. The phrase *min wara'ihim* (from behind) metaphorically illustrates that divine oversight surrounds human actions from every direction – past, present, and future. Classical Shia commentators like Allamah Tabatabai explain this as a reminder that no injustice escapes Allah’s justice, even if worldly power appears dominant. Historically, this verse strengthened early Muslims facing persecution in Makkah, affirming that their oppressors’ arrogance would ultimately crumble before divine law.  

Today, this verse reassures believers facing moral, social, or political oppression. It teaches that reliance on Allah (tawakkul) is not passive but rooted in the certainty that divine justice prevails. Modern Muslims can apply this by resisting despair in adversity, trusting that unethical systems or individuals cannot evade accountability. Simultaneously, it warns against complacency in wrongdoing, as Allah’s "encompassing" awareness applies to all. The verse invites self-reflection: just as oppressors are monitored, our own actions – good or harmful – exist within the same divine framework. By internalizing this truth, Muslims cultivate both humility and courage, aligning their lives with ethical integrity and trust in Allah’s ultimate plan.
20.layer2:
In Surah al-Burooj (85:20), the phrase "Allah encompasses them from behind" has been interpreted by classical Shia exegetes as a profound articulation of divine omniscience and omnipotence, contextualized within the surah's themes of divine justice and the futility of opposing truth. Both Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* emphasize that the term "muhit" (encompassing) denotes Allah's absolute knowledge and control over all creation, transcending temporal and spatial limitations. Tabrisi explains that Allah's "encompassing" occurs "from behind" to signify that His knowledge penetrates the hidden dimensions of human actions and intentions, including their consequences in the unseen realm (*ghayb*). This aligns with the Shia theological principle that divine knowledge envelops all aspects of existence, past and future, rendering no deed or thought beyond His awareness.

Tabatabai expands this concept by linking it to the ontological dependency of creation upon the Creator. He notes that Allah's encompassing is not merely observational but existential: all beings are perpetually sustained and bounded by His will, making escape from divine decree impossible. This interpretation resonates with the Shia understanding of *qada' wa qadar* (divine predestination), wherein human free will operates within the framework of Allah's overarching knowledge and plan. The verse thus serves as both a warning to oppressors—such as those referenced in the surah who persecuted believers—and a reassurance to the faithful that divine justice prevails through Allah's all-encompassing authority.

The verse also subtly reinforces the Shia doctrine of Imamah, as the Imam’s role as a guide is understood to function within the sphere of Allah's comprehensive knowledge. Classical commentators stress that this "encompassing" ensures the ultimate triumph of truth, a theme central to Shia eschatology. By situating the verse within the broader discourse on divine justice and human accountability, Shia exegesis underscores the interdependence of theological principles and practical ethics in Islamic doctrine.
20.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Burooj (85:20) – "While Allah encompasses them from behind" – is often interpreted as a profound reminder of divine omnipresence and cosmic accountability. Scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi emphasize that this "encompassing" (muhit) transcends physicality, reflecting Allah’s infinite knowledge and control over all systems of existence, from subatomic interactions to galactic expansions. This aligns with modern physics’ concept of quantum fields permeating the universe, suggesting a scientific metaphor for divine immanence – though theologians caution against conflating metaphysical truths with material frameworks.

Philosophically, thinkers such as Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali frame this verse as addressing humanity’s existential anxiety in an age of fragmentation. The "encompassing" divine presence counters modern feelings of isolation, offering spiritual coherence in a world grappling with climate crises, AI ethics, and geopolitical conflicts. Socially, it challenges systems of oppression: if Allah surrounds all power structures, as scholar Sayyed Ammar Nakshawani notes, no tyranny – whether political, economic, or environmental – escapes divine justice. This resonates with global movements for equity and ecological stewardship.

Interfaith dialogues draw parallels with panentheistic concepts in Christian mysticism (God “in whom we live and move”) and Hindu Brahman, fostering multicultural solidarity in addressing shared crises. The verse’s contemporary urgency lies in its call to recognize interconnectedness – that environmental destruction or social injustice ultimately "encompasses" us all. In digital surveillance societies, it reframes omnipresence as compassionate witness rather than invasive control, inviting ethical alignment with divine consciousness. As humanity navigates unprecedented challenges, this verse becomes a compass for holistic responsibility – spiritual, ecological, and social – under the infinite embrace of the Divine.
20.layer4:
The verse "While Allah encompasses them from behind" (85:20) unveils a profound reality of divine omnipresence and omniscience, illuminated by the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (as). Imam Ali (as) states in Nahj al-Balagha: *"Allah’s knowledge penetrates into the secret of whispers and the hiddens of the darknesses."* This verse reminds believers that no thought, action, or hidden reality escapes Allah’s encompassing awareness – a truth both awe-inspiring and comforting for the spiritually conscious.  

Imam Sadiq (as) taught that this "encompassing" manifests through two dimensions: as a warning to oppressors who imagine their tyranny is concealed, and as divine protection for the faithful. He explained: *"The believer walks in the shelter of Allah’s mercy, while the disbeliever walks under the shadow of His justice."* Here, the Imam connects Allah’s all-surrounding presence to the principle of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship) – for those who embrace the guidance of the Ahlul Bayt (as), this encompassing becomes a fortress of spiritual security.  

Lady Fatimah (sa) emphasized this truth in her famous sermon: *"He initiated creation out of nothing… while knowing what lies within breasts."* Her words reveal that Allah’s encompassing knowledge is inseparable from His creative power and mercy. Practically, this demands constant *muraqaba* (spiritual vigilance) – nurturing awareness that every moment is witnessed by the Divine, and aligning one’s inner state with outward actions.  

The Shia tradition teaches that embracing the *Imamah* – the luminous guidance of the sinless Imams (as) – allows believers to navigate this divine encompassment correctly. As Imam Ali (as) advised: *"Make your self accountable before you’re held accountable."* Through daily self-reckoning, seeking intercession via the Ahlul Bayt (as), and anchoring oneself in their teachings, the believer transforms Allah’s all-seeing presence from a source of fear into a wellspring of spiritual growth and divine proximity.

اصطلاح * موہیت * (محیط) اللہ کے تمام علم اور طاقت کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے ، جو وقت ، جگہ اور انسانی تاثر سے ماورا ہے۔ جملہ * من واریہیم * (پیچھے سے) استعاراتی طور پر واضح کرتا ہے کہ الہی نگرانی انسانی عمل کو ہر سمت سے گھیر لیتی ہے - ماضی ، حال اور مستقبل۔ الامہ تبتابائی جیسے کلاسیکی شیعہ مبصرین کو یہ یاد دہانی کے طور پر بیان کیا گیا ہے کہ کوئی ناانصافی اللہ کے انصاف سے نہیں بچتی ، چاہے دنیاوی طاقت غالب دکھائی دے۔ تاریخی طور پر ، اس آیت نے ابتدائی مسلمانوں کو مکہ مکرمہ میں ظلم و ستم کا سامنا کرنا پڑا ، اور اس بات کی تصدیق کی کہ ان کے جابروں کا تکبر بالآخر الہی قانون سے پہلے ہی گر جائے گا۔  

آج ، یہ آیت اخلاقی ، معاشرتی ، یا سیاسی جبر کا سامنا کرنے والے مومنین کو یقین دلا رہی ہے۔ یہ سکھاتا ہے کہ اللہ پر انحصار غیر فعال نہیں ہے بلکہ اس بات کی جڑ سے جڑ ہے کہ خدائی انصاف کے غالب ہے۔ جدید مسلمان مصیبتوں میں مایوسی کا مقابلہ کرکے اس کا اطلاق کرسکتے ہیں ، اس پر اعتماد کرتے ہوئے کہ غیر اخلاقی نظام یا افراد احتساب سے بچ نہیں سکتے ہیں۔ اس کے ساتھ ہی ، یہ غلط کاموں میں خوشنودی کے خلاف انتباہ کرتا ہے ، کیونکہ اللہ کی "محیط" بیداری سب پر لاگو ہوتی ہے۔ آیت خود کی عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے: جس طرح جابروں کی نگرانی کی جاتی ہے ، اسی طرح ہمارے اپنے اعمال-اچھے یا نقصان دہ-اسی الہی فریم ورک میں موجود ہیں۔ اس سچائی کو اندرونی بناتے ہوئے ، مسلمان اپنی زندگی کو اخلاقی سالمیت اور اللہ کے حتمی منصوبے پر اعتماد کے ساتھ ہم آہنگی اور ہمت دونوں کو فروغ دیتے ہیں۔

تبتابائی نے اس تصور کو تخلیق کار پر تخلیق کے اونٹولوجیکل انحصار سے جوڑ کر اس کو بڑھایا ہے۔ وہ نوٹ کرتا ہے کہ اللہ کا محیط محض مشاہداتی نہیں بلکہ وجودی ہے: تمام مخلوقات مستقل طور پر برقرار رہتے ہیں اور اس کی مرضی سے پابند ہیں ، جس سے الہی فرمان سے فرار ناممکن ہے۔ یہ تشریح * قادا 'وا قادر * (الہی پیش گوئی) کی شیعہ تفہیم کے ساتھ گونجتی ہے ، جس میں اللہ کے اہم علم اور منصوبے کے فریم ورک کے اندر ہیومن فری مرضی کام کرتی ہے۔ اس طرح یہ آیت ظالموں کے لئے ایک انتباہ کا کام کرتی ہے-جیسا کہ سورہ میں ان لوگوں کا حوالہ دیا گیا ہے جنہوں نے مومنوں کو ظلم کیا تھا-اور وفاداروں کو یہ یقین دہانی کرائی گئی ہے کہ الہام انصاف کے ذریعہ الہام انصاف کا حامل ہے۔

21.layer1:
In Surah Al-Burooj, verse 21, Allah responds to the disbelievers’ rejection of the Quran with a profound declaration: *"Bal huwa Qur’anun Majid"* (But this is an honored Qur’an). The verse shifts focus from the arrogance of those who deny divine truth to the inherent nobility of the Quran itself. The term *"Majid"* (honored) carries deep significance, denoting grandeur, dignity, and exalted status. Shia scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* explain that this verse affirms the Quran’s timeless spiritual and moral authority, transcending human skepticism. It is not merely a book but a living miracle, revered in the *"Lawh Mahfuz"* (Preserved Tablet), as mentioned in earlier verses, symbolizing its divine origin and protection from corruption.

Historically, this Meccan surah emerged amid intense persecution of early Muslims, including the tragic event of the "People of the Ditch" (Ashab al-Ukhdud), who were burned for their faith. Verse 21 reassures believers that the Quran’s truth and majesty cannot be diminished by oppression or denial. The disbelievers’ mockery is contrasted with the Quran’s eternal honor, a theme central to Shia theology, which emphasizes the Quran’s inseparable link to the guidance of the Ahlul Bayt—the Prophet’s purified family, who embody its teachings.

For contemporary Muslims, this verse invites reflection on how to honor the Quran beyond ritual recitation. It calls for internalizing its moral framework—justice, compassion, and integrity—in daily life. In an age of doubt and materialism, the Quran remains a *"Majid"* compass, urging believers to seek deeper understanding through its verses and the interpretive wisdom of the Ahlul Bayt. By aligning actions with its principles, Muslims uphold its honor, transforming it from a sacred text into a lived reality that resists oppression and elevates humanity.
21.layer2:
In the exegesis of Surah al-Burooj (85:21), classical Shia commentators emphasize the ontological and theological supremacy of the Qur'an as a manifestation of divine speech, countering the deniers' rejection referenced in preceding verses. The term *majid* (honored) is interpreted not merely as an attribute of worldly prestige but as an essential quality rooted in the Qur'an's divine origin and its inseparable connection to the unseen realm (*al-ghayb*). As Allama Tabatabai elucidates in *Al-Mizan*, the verse's emphatic structure ("بل هو") establishes a categorical distinction between the limited perceptions of disbelievers and the Qur'an's transcendent reality as a "preserved tablet" (85:22), eternally guarded from corruption. This reflects the Shia theological principle of the Qur'an's *ismah* (infallible protection), which extends to its authentic interpretation through the divinely appointed Imams of the Ahlul Bayt.

Tabrisi's *Majma al-Bayan* highlights the linguistic depth of *majid*, deriving from the root *majd* (glory), which signifies the Qur'an's unparalleled status above all created beings and previous scriptures. This aligns with the Shia doctrine of the Qur'an as the culmination of divine guidance, whose full comprehension is only accessible through the hermeneutical authority of the Imams, as stated by Imam Jafar al-Sadiq: "The Book of God has four dimensions: expression (*ibarah*), allusion (*isharah*), subtleties (*lata'if*), and profound truths (*haqa'iq*) – the latter are reserved for the pure ones [Ahlul Bayt]." 

The verse's theological implications extend to Shia jurisprudence, affirming the Qur'an as the primary source of legislative and ethical principles, while simultaneously requiring its exegesis to be grounded in the Prophetic tradition (*sunnah*) and the teachings of the Imams. This dual emphasis on textual supremacy and authorized interpretation safeguards against both literalist reductionism and esoteric deviation, embodying the Shia vision of the Qur'an as a living, dynamic guide under the guardianship (*wilayah*) of the Ahlul Bayt.
21.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Burooj’s declaration *“But this is an honored Qur’an”* (85:21) is often framed as both a theological anchor and a call to dynamic engagement with modernity. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his exegesis, emphasizes the Qur’an’s *majeed* (honored) nature as a timeless source of dignity and guidance, transcending historical or cultural reductionism. This aligns with thinkers like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, who interprets the verse as affirming the Qur’an’s capacity to address evolving human questions—from bioethics to social justice—through its layered wisdom.  

Modern scientific discourse amplifies this perspective. The Qur’an’s description of cosmic order (e.g., “the heaven with constellations,” referenced earlier in the surah) resonates with contemporary astrophysics, inviting believers to see divine majesty in scientific inquiry. Scholars like Dr. Mehdi Golshani, a physicist and philosopher, argue that the Qur’an’s honor lies in its ability to harmonize faith and reason, urging Muslims to embrace empirical study as a form of *tafakkur* (contemplation).  

Socially, the verse’s context—critiquing persecutors of faith (85:4-10)—speaks to modern struggles against religious oppression, Islamophobia, and systemic injustice. Ayatollah Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari links the Qur’an’s “honor” to its advocacy for human dignity, urging communities to combat extremism and poverty as violations of divine justice. In multicultural societies, this verse also fosters interfaith dialogue; its universal reverence for sacred texts parallels Vatican II’s *Nostra Aetate*, which acknowledges shared spiritual truths.  

Philosophically, the “honored Qur’an” challenges postmodern relativism by asserting objective moral truths while remaining adaptable to cultural contexts. For youth navigating identity crises, it offers stability without rigidity—a balance scholars like Dr. Liyakat Takim describe as “rooted cosmopolitanism.” Ultimately, this verse invites a world in crisis—ecological collapse, polarization, existential anxiety—to seek solutions in a text that honors both transcendence and human potential.
21.layer4:
The verse "But this is an honored Qur'an" (85:21) unveils a profound reality echoed in the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them). Imam Ali al-Ridha (as) states, "The Qur'an’s honor lies in its connection to the Divine Throne and the purified ones [the Ahlul Bayt] who carry its secrets." This "honor" (majeed) is not merely linguistic excellence but a living reality intertwined with the cosmic role of Wilayah. The Qur'an’s majesty flows from its divine origin and its inseparable bond with those entrusted to manifest its hidden truths.

Lady Fatimah (sa) taught, "The Qur'an is a luminous guide whose light cannot be extinguished, a sharp sword whose edge cannot be dulled." Its honor lies in its capacity to elevate souls through the gateway of the Imams’ teachings. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) explains, "The Qur'an possesses an outer form and an inner essence. Its essence is the knowledge granted to the Ahlul Bayt, and its form is what is recited." Thus, the verse’s declaration of honor points to the Qur'an’s uncreated reality, preserved in the hearts of the Infallible Guides who embody its living wisdom.

Practically, honoring the Qur'an requires recognizing its spiritual guardians. Imam Ali (as) advises, "Bind yourself to the Qur'an through our Ahlul Bayt, for they are the firm rope of God." This means studying Qur'anic verses through the lens of the Imams’ interpretations, aligning one’s life with their ethical teachings, and seeking proximity to God by loving His chosen representatives. Daily recitation becomes transformative when accompanied by reflection on Hadith al-Thaqalayn’s principle – holding fast to both the Book and the purified Household. The Qur'an’s honor is ultimately realized when its verses illuminate the heart through the light of Muhammad and his Family (peace upon them all)

22.layer1:
In Surah Al-Burooj, verse 22, Allah describes the Quran as being inscribed in a "Lawhin Mahfuz" – a Preserved Slate. This verse reassures believers of the divine protection and eternal nature of the Quran, emphasizing that its message remains uncorrupted and safeguarded from distortion. The term *Lawh* (Slate) evokes imagery of a celestial tablet, symbolizing the totality of Allah’s knowledge and decrees, while *Mahfuz* (Preserved) underscores its inviolability. Shia scholars like Allamah Tabatabai explain that the Lawhin Mahfuz transcends physicality, representing a metaphysical reality where Allah’s eternal wisdom, including the Quran’s truths, is perfectly stored and protected from alteration.

Historically, this verse was revealed during the Meccan period, a time when early Muslims faced persecution and attempts to suppress the Quran’s message. By affirming the Quran’s divine preservation, it fortified believers’ confidence in its authenticity. The concept of preservation also aligns with Shia teachings about the role of the Ahlul Bayt, particularly the Imams, who are seen as guardians of the Quran’s esoteric meanings and its practical application across generations. Just as the Lawhin Mahfuz protects the text, the Imams preserve its true interpretation, ensuring guidance remains accessible.

For contemporary Muslims, this verse offers profound reassurance: the Quran’s teachings are timeless and divinely shielded, providing a stable moral compass amid modern challenges. It invites reflection on the responsibility to uphold the Quran’s values, seek knowledge through its rightful interpreters (the Ahlul Bayt), and trust in its unbroken connection to divine truth. Practically, this encourages Muslims to deepen their engagement with the Quran, prioritize its preservation in their hearts and actions, and remain steadfast in faith, knowing its guidance is eternally secure.
22.layer2:
In classical Shia exegesis, the verse "In a Preserved Slate" (Qur’an 85:22) is interpreted as a profound affirmation of divine knowledge, the Qur’an’s ontological origin, and its protection from corruption. Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, elucidates that the "Preserved Slate" (Lawh Mahfuz) transcends physicality, representing the eternal repository of God’s knowledge encompassing all cosmic realities, decrees, and sacred scriptures. This aligns with the Shia theological principle of *‘ilm al-ghayb* (knowledge of the unseen), wherein divine omniscience encompasses past, present, and future in an immutable register accessible only to God and those He has chosen—namely, the Prophets and Ahl al-Bayt.  

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, emphasizes the Qur’an’s celestial origin, noting that the Preserved Slate safeguards the scripture’s integrity against distortion (*tahrif*), a doctrine central to Shia belief in the Qur’an’s inviolability. This concept intersects with the Shia understanding of *ismah* (divinely granted infallibility), as the Imams—being inheritors of the Prophet’s knowledge—are entrusted with interpreting the Qur’an’s esoteric meanings (*batin*) preserved within this metaphysical tablet.  

The verse also underpins Shia jurisprudence, as the Qur’an’s preservation necessitates the existence of infallible guides (Imams) to transmit and apply its rulings authentically. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, as cited in traditions, described the Lawh Mahfuz as encompassing not only scripture but the totality of divine will, including the destinies of creation and the station of the Imams as custodians of this knowledge. Thus, the verse reinforces the Shia paradigm of *walayah* (divine guardianship), linking the Qur’an’s heavenly source to the Imamah’s role in sustaining its living guidance.  

In sum, classical Shia scholarship views this verse as a theological cornerstone affirming the unity of divine knowledge, the Qur’an’s eternal protection, and the necessity of the Ahl al-Bayt as its authoritative interpreters.
22.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Burooj’s reference to the Quran being inscribed in a “Preserved Slate” (Lawh Mahfooz) is often interpreted as a profound metaphor for divine knowledge’s timelessness and its immunity to distortion. Scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi emphasize that this “slate” transcends physicality, symbolizing an eternal metaphysical repository of truth guarded by Allah—a concept resonating with the Shia belief in the infallible guidance of the Ahlul Bayt as custodians of this knowledge. Modern thinkers, such as Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, link this idea to the Quran’s role as a stable moral compass in an era of rapid technological change and ethical ambiguity, where misinformation and cultural erosion threaten societal cohesion.

Scientifically, some scholars draw parallels with quantum physics’ “implicate order” or the cosmic information field, suggesting the Lawh Mahfooz reflects a universe sustained by divine will—a framework where natural laws and human accountability coexist. Philosophically, it challenges materialist worldviews by affirming transcendent purpose, a theme echoed in interfaith dialogues. Jewish and Christian traditions similarly reference divine “heavenly tablets,” fostering shared ethical ground in multicultural societies.

Socially, the verse’s emphasis on preservation speaks to contemporary struggles: climate activists invoke it to advocate for safeguarding Earth’s balance, while digital ethicists contrast humanity’s fragile data storage with the “Preserved Slate’s” perfection. In a fragmented world, this verse reassures believers that divine truth remains uncorrupted, urging communities to align with justice and wisdom—a call amplified by Shia leaders addressing crises from AI ethics to refugee rights. Ultimately, it bridges cosmic permanence and human impermanence, inviting reflection on what endures beyond transient challenges.

The verse "Inscribed in a Preserved Slate" (85:22) is illuminated by the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) as a profound allusion to the eternal, protected reality of divine knowledge and the sacred station of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship). Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) taught that the "Preserved Slate" refers not merely to a celestial tablet but to the purified hearts of the Prophet and his purified progeny, who are the custodians of Allah’s unaltered truth. He states, *"The Preserved Slate is the heart of the Messenger of Allah, and the hearts of his successors [the Imams]. In it is the knowledge of everything, preserved from alteration or distortion."*  

This verse embodies the Shia understanding that the essence of the Quran’s guidance and the secrets of creation are safeguarded within the spiritual reality of the Ahlul Bayt. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) emphasized this truth, declaring, *"We are the speaking Book of Allah, the luminous light of His wisdom."* The "Preserved Slate" thus symbolizes the infallible Imamah – a divine institution through which the inner meanings of revelation are eternally accessible to those who seek with sincerity.  

Practically, this invites believers to anchor their spiritual development in love for and adherence to the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught that purifying the heart through remembrance of Allah and reflection on the Quran’s esoteric truths opens the door to this "Preserved" knowledge. By aligning one’s life with the principles of justice, devotion, and ethical purity exemplified by the Imams, the seeker gradually perceives the luminous realities veiled within the Quranic verses. The slate’s "preservation" thus manifests in the spiritual protection granted to those who walk the path of *Wilayah*, holding fast to the rope of the Ahlul Bayt in thought, word, and deed.

کلاسیکی شیعہ کی توثیق میں ، آیت "ایک محفوظ سلیٹ میں" (قرآن مجید 85:22) کو خدائی علم ، قرآن کی نظریاتی اصل ، اور بدعنوانی سے تحفظ کی گہری تصدیق کے طور پر سمجھا جاتا ہے۔ تبتابائی ، *المزان *میں ، اس بات کی وضاحت کرتا ہے کہ "محفوظ سلیٹ" (لاک مہفوز) جسمانییت سے بالاتر ہے ، جو خدا کے علم کے ابدی ذخیرے کی نمائندگی کرتا ہے جس میں تمام کائناتی حقائق ، احکامات اور مقدس صحیفوں کو شامل کیا گیا ہے۔ یہ * ‘Ilm Alghayb * (غیب کا علم) کے شیعہ مذہبی اصول کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہے ، جس میں خدائی اومن سائنس ماضی ، حال اور مستقبل کو صرف خدا کے لئے قابل رسائی رجسٹر میں شامل کرتی ہے اور انھوں نے جو منتخب کیا ہے-یعنی نبیوں اور اہل البیت۔

اس آیت میں شیعہ فقہ کو بھی سمجھا جاتا ہے ، کیونکہ قرآن مجید کے تحفظ کو اپنے احکامات کو مستند طور پر منتقل کرنے اور اس کا اطلاق کرنے کے لئے ناقابل تسخیر رہنما (آئی ایم اے ایم) کے وجود کی ضرورت ہوتی ہے۔ امام جعفر السادق ، جیسا کہ روایات میں پیش کیا گیا ہے ، نے لوہ مہفوز کو نہ صرف صحیفہ پر محیط قرار دیا ہے بلکہ الہی مرضی کی مکمل حیثیت بھی شامل ہے ، جس میں تخلیق کی تقدیر اور اماموں کے اسٹیشن کو بھی اس علم کے نگران قرار دیا گیا ہے۔ اس طرح ، آیت * والیاہ * (الہی سرپرستی) کے شیعہ تمثیل کو تقویت بخشتی ہے ، اور قرآن مجید کے آسمانی ذریعہ کو اپنی رہنمائی کو برقرار رکھنے میں امامہ کے کردار سے جوڑتی ہے۔  

خلاصہ یہ ہے کہ کلاسیکی شیعہ اسکالرشپ اس آیت کو الہی علم کے اتحاد ، قرآن مجید کے ابدی تحفظ ، اور اے ایچ ایل ال بیت کی ضرورت کو اس کے مستند ترجمان کے طور پر تصدیق کرنے والی تھیولوجیکل کارن اسٹون کے طور پر دیکھتی ہے۔
